channel.title: Simplifying Redstone [tutorials] [new video]
channel.description:
[center]Hey everyone, here are a few videos I made to show off (hardly) advanced redstone circuits.

Redstone RAM
[url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4xTEfU1ODiI]http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4xTEfU1ODiI[/url]
Concepting a new RAM idea?

7 Segment display

item.title: Simplifying Redstone [tutorials] [new video]
item.dc:creator: @shrogg shrogg
item.description:
@shrogg wrote:

But that removes half of the fun of making these things, say, if you could make a 16 bit cpu with 128 functions and 512 bytes of ram, and its only 15/15 blocks, how much of a sence of achivment would that bring?

Read full topic

item.title: Simplifying Redstone [tutorials] [new video]
item.dc:creator: @LilXCj LilXCj
item.description:
@LilXCj wrote:

Like I said before, I hope Notch implements IC chips as blocks instead of a combination of redstone blocks. Would make much more compact designs.

Try to make a 3-bit counter (0-7) with a seven segment display. Our engineering course (3rd level) which deeply involved digital electronics (IC chips and logic gates and the sorts) ended with making one on a DLB board and a program called Mulltisim. Clocks and such are some of the hardest to do as well.

Read full topic

item.title: Simplifying Redstone [tutorials] [new video]
item.dc:creator: @shrogg shrogg
item.description:
@shrogg wrote:

Well i guess it started with my first ALU which was HUGE then i realised how people were making things out of redstone and over building them.
and i got stuck, i love MC and i have started to love logic and the making of new and intresting things?

Also, i just linked a few more vids
Enjoy

Read full topic

item.description:
@durial12 wrote:
